original_text:
See It Be It
•	Look around you and name something that you can see. For example, a tree or a cup
•	Say to your child “I see a tree, let’s be it”
•	Countdown from 5 and make the shape of a tree with your bodies. Be as big and silly as possible.
•	Now let your child have a turn. What can they see?
•	If you can, go outside and be in nature. If you can’t, play it inside. 
•	When you’ve done it a few times, add moves and sounds!
text_to_read:

•	Now let your child have a turn. What can they see?
•	If you can, go outside and be in nature. If you can’t, play it inside. 
•	When you’ve done it a few times, add moves and sounds!
label: Activity-Child04-Active-See-it-be-it_c140c990-6cc4-47ea-8f0f-7e0d1162c8bf_af76ba9e-14d7-483a-a972-ce48bfd15670

original_text:
Story time
•	Start the story with “Once upon a time there was a…”
•	Let your child make up the next sentence
•	Then you make up a sentence
•	Take turns until you have a wonderful new story
•	Make sure to end the story on a positive note.
•	Ask your child what was their favourite part of the story!

original_text:
Superpowers
•	Think of a superpower. For example, going anywhere instantly, travelling in time, reading minds. 
•	Ask your child “If you had the superpower to […] how would you use it?
•	Encourage them to give their superhero a name and act it out. 
•	Now let them choose a super power for you
•	Make sure you act it out too!

original_text:
Three options
•	Think of three different situations. For example, driving a car, sailing a boat or flying a plane
•	Say them to your child and ask, “Which would you prefer?”
•	Ask them why?
•	Now think of three more situations or ask your child to do it for you

original_text:
Worms Go Home
•	Lie on your tummies and pretend your index fingers are a wiggly worm. 
•	With your other hand make a worm house by making a circle with your fingers and thumb and place it on the floor. 
•	Call out an instruction for your finger to touch, like “Worms on noses” or “Worms on ears”
•	When you call out “Worms go home”, your wiggly worm has to find a worm house as quickly as possible. 
•	The last worm to find a home calls out the instructions next. 
•	Keep playing until you feel rejuvenated from lying down.

original_text:
Here are some things you can do when your teen shares something difficult with you:
• Take a deep breath before you respond. 
• Listen to what your child is saying. Notice how they are feeling.
• Notice how you feel. Ask yourself, "What does my child need right now?" 
• Reassure your child that you are there for them. 
• You can deal with the consequences later but right now your child needs you.
• Discuss possible solutions or next steps to take action. 
• Remind your child again that you love them and thank them for sharing with you.
text_to_read:

• Reassure your child that you are there for them. 
• You can deal with the consequences later but right now your child needs you.
• Discuss possible solutions or next steps to take action. 
• Remind your child again that you love them and thank them for sharing with you.
label: Content-Extra-Behave-Crisis_75323c92-5879-457c-b6f8-243a9e5875da_e04fc9da-60b9-4562-ad86-9a370d8f49c3

original_text:
Mirror
•	This game can be played in pairs or even as a group
•	Stand facing each other or in a circle  
•	One person leads first while everyone else must copy, trying to move exactly at the same time as the leader.
•	Make sure the leader moves slowly enough for everyone to follow! Explore moving different body parts and in different levels.
•	After a while, switch who is leading. Give everyone a chance to lead
•	Try it with no leaders!

original_text:
Run Around and Do This 
•	Everyone runs around the room or garden.  Make sure the space is large enough and safe
•	At any time, someone can stop somewhere and say, “When you get over here, you do this!”  
•	What you do can be anything: push-ups, singing a song, crying, jumping… 
•	The more you play, there are more and more things to do in more and more places.  
•	Each person can decide where to go when.  
•	It’s fun to interact with other people who are doing the same thing as you!

original_text:
Blind Dragon 
•	This game is great if you have at least 4 people
•	Tell the story about a ferocious dragon who lived near a village. He would sneak into the village at night and steal people’s treasures – anything they loved.  Anybody who tried to take their treasure back would be eaten alive.  This continued for many years until the dragon became old, fat, and blind from sitting on his treasure and gazing at the glare of the gold coins. Then the townspeople could try and sneak into his lair and steal back their relatives’ treasure. 
•	One person plays the dragon. Dragon sits blindfolded or with eyes closed surrounded by a pile of treasure. 
•	Everyone has one piece of treasure that they must steal back. 
•	If the dragon hears you and points at you, you must go back to the starting place. 
•	Only one person can try to get the treasure at a time.

original_text:
What Are You Doing? 
•	This game is best when more than 2 people play
•	One person pretends to be doing something – for example, combing hair or making dinner  
•	Another person asks, “What are you doing?”
•	The first person needs to say something that has nothing to do with combing hair, for example, “Tying my shoes.”  
•	The second person then starts pretending to tie their shoes until a new person asks, “What are you doing?” 
•	The answer must always be something different than what you are actually doing!

original_text:
Dancing with Angels
•	This activity helps children learn how to lead. It also builds trust between you and your child
•	Play a piece of music that is gentle and relaxed to encourage smooth and calming movement.
•	One person goes first and closes their eyes while the other person is the guardian angel or protector
•	The guardian angel must protect the person with their eyes closed from harm while gently dancing together
•	When the music ends, the dancer can open their eyes before switching roles

3. Let your baby take the lead

6. Talk to your baby
7. You can have quality time with your baby anytime!

Here are 6 tips on how to make One-on-One Time a positive experience for you and your teen:

1. Do it every day
2. Let your teen choose the activity
3. Follow your teen's lead
4. Give your teen your full attention
5. Show your teen you are really listening
6. Have fun!

To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to "6". You can also type "N" to move on.

original_text:
Here are some tips for how to help your child prepare for bedtime:
• Try to have regular bedtimes each day as much as possible.
• Try to make it quiet and the lights in the room dim. 
• Spend some time with your child. You can sing a lullaby or tell a calm story.
• Give your child a hug and kiss goodnight before leaving the room.

original_text:
Here are some tips for how we can help our children learn how to cope with their emotions:

1. Be open to your child
2. Share your own feelings
3. Help your child learn how to talk about feelings
4. Talking about difficult emotions
5. Notice the positive emotions
6. Show your child that you care

To learn more about one of these, type "1" to "6". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.

original_text:
1. Be open to your child

Your child will look to you for support and reassurance. Listen to your children when they share how they are feeling. Accept how they feel and give them comfort.
text_to_read:
1. Be open to your child

Your child will look to you for support and reassurance. Listen to your children when they share how they are feeling. Accept how they feel and give them comfort.
label: Content-Extra-Behave-Be-open-to-emotions_03feef2f-d0f7-461d-ba19-f24f1756cef5_5857acfe-39a9-4ad0-af52-3f12d1ad7e30

original_text:
2. Share your own feelings

When you share your own feelings with your children, you help them recognise their own feelings. It can also help your children learn self-discipline and to understand their own feelings.
text_to_read:
2. Share your own feelings

When you share your own feelings with your children, you help them recognise their own feelings. It can also help your children learn self-discipline and to understand their own feelings.
label: Content-Extra-Behave-Be-open-to-emotions_b9873193-bc95-4216-81d7-acb6842ca075_3e2f7f23-5597-4506-850c-2d16d0293c31

original_text:
3. Help your child learn how to talk about feelings

There are 6 basic emotions: Happy, Sad, Angry, Disgusted, Surprised, and Afraid. Even babies can feel and express these emotions. As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.
text_to_read:
3. Help your child learn how to talk about feelings

There are 6 basic emotions: Happy, Sad, Angry, Disgusted, Surprised, and Afraid. Even babies can feel and express these emotions. As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.
label: Content-Extra-Behave-Be-open-to-emotions_d20cb799-b5aa-4a83-b867-62e7b12a651e_5b1d41d4-3089-402d-825b-4d58d599d95d

original_text:
4. Talking about difficult emotions

It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Many of us were told not to cry when we were sad or laugh when we were happy. This may be especially the case for boys and men.
text_to_read:
4. Talking about difficult emotions

It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Many of us were told not to cry when we were sad or laugh when we were happy. This may be especially the case for boys and men.
label: Content-Extra-Behave-Be-open-to-emotions_7529aa8f-f7af-4cb2-a2a2-7e7835fa4c2f_44b5c6ee-3f8b-4404-a30b-ab2b8cb1e7be

original_text:
5. Notice the positive emotions

Talking about feelings can help children manage anger, disappointment, and frustration. It can also help your child be more aware of positive emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness. It can also allow children to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!
text_to_read:

original_text:
6. Show your child that you care

Use physical and verbal support to make your child feel accepted and loved. A hug or saying, "I understand," can mean a lot. Remind your child that you are there for them and that they can always talk to you.

original_text:
When something bad happens, we often get upset and blame our children. But what they really need is someone to help them work through their problems. 
Take a Pause! Become aware of anger and stress. Take a deep breath or count to 10 before you react. Then respond in a calmer way.
text_to_read:

original_text:
Here are 6 steps on how we can reduce negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like tantrums using what we call Ignore:

1. Try to redirect your child’s attention
2. Make sure it is a behaviour you can ignore
3. Ignore the behaviour not your child
4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour
5. Be consistent when ignoring
6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times.

To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to "6". You can also type "N" to move on.

In summary, consequences should be...
• Realistic: Consider the age of your child
• Immediate: Give them as soon as possible
• Fair: Make sure the consequence is not too harsh
• Consistent: Make sure you can follow through if you have to
• The last resort: Try to encourage the positive behaviour to happen more often!

original_text:
Get active!
•	Come up with three types of exercise together. For example, walking, jogging, soccer or dancing
•	Pick one together and try it out. 
•	If you both like it, decide how often you are going to do it. Once or twice a week? Every morning?
•	Together think of ways to make it even more fun. Can you jog to a certain point? Take turns in being the coach? Motivate each other with a small free reward?

original_text:
Co-chef
•	Ask your teen what kind of meal they would like to eat.
•	Prepare it together! The first time, you may need to guide them. 
•	Once your teen knows how to prepare the meal, let them take the lead and follow their instructions.
•	 Let each child and teen in the house have a turn at being the head chef.
•	You can even help them make a budget for ingredients!

original_text:
What Are You Doing? 
•	This game is best when more than 2 people play
•	One person pretends to be doing something – for example, combing hair or making dinner  
•	Another person asks, “What are you doing?”
•	The first person needs to say something that has nothing to do with combing hair, for example, “Tying my shoes.”  
•	The second person then starts pretending to tie their shoes until a new person asks, “What are you doing?” 
•	The answer must always be something different than what you are actually doing!

original_text:
Crazy Chicken
•	Shake your left hands in the air 8 times while counting to 8 
•	Do it as fast and loud as you can
•	Repeat with your other hand. Repeat with both feet
•	Do it 7 times, then 6 times and continue until you get to 1.
•	Everyone calls out “Crazy chicken” and does their best crazy chicken dance!

original_text:
Pass the Snap  
•	This game is best with at least 3 people
•	Start in a circle and pass one snap around the circle (or clap if you cannot snap)
•	You snap once to throw the snap and once to catch it. Look at the person you are throwing to.  
•	The direction (up, down, straight, curved, rolling the ground) and force (hard, soft, medium) that you throw the snap should affect how the person catches it.  
•	You can bounce the snap, throw it in the air, and catch it a few times before passing it.  
•	When everyone gets good at this, you can start moving around the room, still passing the snap.  
•	Can you throw under the leg?  Behind the back?  Through your head?  Intercept a pass? Have fun with the snap!

•	At the end of each day, take a minute to think about the day.

original_text:
Make a list of healthy activities that you like to do. Here are some suggestions:
Listening to your favourite music
• Going for a walk (if allowed)
• Doing some exercise
• Drinking a cup of tea by yourself
• Calling up a friend
• Singing, dancing, praying, or reading
• Sitting in the sun with your eyes closed
• Watching your favourite T.V. show
Pick one and do it today!

original_text:
2 Truths, 1 Lie
•	Think of three statements about yourself. Two must be true and one must be a lie.
•	It might help to think of wishes, dreams, likes or dislikes. For example, I hate bananas, I love ice cream and I really wish I could sing. 
•	Say them to your partner or friends. Ask them to guess which one is a lie. 
•	Did they guess correctly? Was it a surprise?
•	Now ask them to do the same. Did you learn something new about each other?

original_text:
Family Work Out
•	Choose a sport or exercise to do together
•	Decide on a schedule. Are you going to do it every day? For how long? 
•	Try it out for a week. 
•	At the end of the week, ask yourself and your family these questions. How´s it going? How did you feel at the start of the week? How do you feel at the end of the week? What can we do differently next week?

•	Decide on a schedule. Are you going to do it every day? For how long? 
•	Try it out for a week. 
•	At the end of the week, ask yourself and your family these questions. How´s it going? How did you feel at the start of the week? How do you feel at the end of the week? What can we do differently next week?
label: Activity-Adult03-Active-Family-work-out_f998c7a6-1727-43c3-b860-f08029fd8120_63a0c0f3-89c0-4c34-ac5b-a9fedf548d0a

original_text:
Crazy Chicken
•	Shake your hand in the air 8 times while counting
•	Do it as fast and loud as you can
•	Repeat with your other hand and both feet
•	Do it 7 times, then 6 times until you get to 1.
•	Call out “Crazy chicken” as loud as you can!
•	Have you released all your stress? If not, do it again even faster and louder!

original_text:
Stop & Listen
• Stop for a moment and close your eyes. 
• How many sounds can you hear? Listen to sounds inside and outside the room. Count them on your fingers. (Pause for 10 seconds)
• How many fingers do you have up? What sounds did you hear? 
• Let’s try again. Can you hear any new sounds this time? Can you hear any sounds inside your own body? (Pause for 10 seconds)
• Open your eyes. What new sounds did you hear?
text_to_read:

original_text:
Release Some Energy
•	Baba da bi da ba da baaa! Pause Power! 
•	What’s Pause Power I hear you say? It’s the ability to transform from a grumpy, angry person into a calm, clear one. 
•	When I’m feeling frustrated I plant my feet firmly on the ground and I breathe in and out three times as slowly as I can. Sometimes I imagine I’m smelling a flower and blowing out a candle. 
•	Da ta! Pause Power! My transformation from grumpy to calm is complete!

•	Bella mama, bella mama hey. 
•	Hey there! How are you feeling today? Do you feel great?!
•	Maybe not. Maybe you shouted again at your children today? Maybe you got angry and said something you don't feel proud of? It’s ok. It’s super stressful right now. 
•	Take a deep breath and think of one thing you did today that you do feel proud of. It doesn't have to be big. And wrap your arms around your body and give yourself a hug. And now think of one thing you did today that you don't feel proud of. What can you do differently tomorrow? And wrap your arms around your body and give yourself a hug. 
•	Bella mama, bella mama, bella mama, bella mama, bella mama, bella mama hey”.
text_to_read:

•	Take a deep breath and think of one thing you did today that you do feel proud of. It doesn't have to be big. And wrap your arms around your body and give yourself a hug. And now think of one thing you did today that you don't feel proud of. What can you do differently tomorrow? And wrap your arms around your body and give yourself a hug. 
•	Bella mama, bella mama, bella mama, bella mama, bella mama, bella mama hey”.

original_text:
Here are some simple tips on how you can make household rules with your children and teens: 

• Involve your child in establishing household rules.
• Make your household rules clear and specific.
• Make sure your child understands the reasons why you are establishing a household rule.
• Make your household rules fair and realistic (just like instructions).
• Praise and simple incentives can help support your child in following a household rule.
• Add only 1 household rule at a time.

• Add only 1 household rule at a time.

Here are some tips for sharing books with your child:
1. Follow your child's interest
2. Use a lifely voice
3. Pointing and naming
4. Be positive and supportive
5. Making actions and links
6. Talking about feelings
7. Babies and books go well together
To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to "7". You can also type "N" to move on.

original_text:
1. Follow your child’s interest
Talk about what interests your child. When your child shows interest in a picture (pointing, patting, looking), use this as a chance to talk about what has attracted your child’s interest
text_to_read:
1. Follow your child’s interest

label: Activity-Baby12-Calm-Book-sharing_455a69e4-a382-4ba4-9a46-d2ef185ace9c_d51a14c5-cb14-4b00-9d6b-eb6df6d5c825

original_text:
2. Use a lively voice
Speak with a lively or animated voice. This will help to keep the child’s attention on the book.

2. Use a lively voice

label: Activity-Baby12-Calm-Book-sharing_2d6587f0-2b1f-4007-8a2f-05e99eb5cb29_b4790323-5f5b-4d24-92cf-d196e65b43bc

original_text: Well done! You have added another tool to your Parenting Tooolbox! Sharing books with your child will help them to learn to speak, think and focus better. It will also help them to get along with others better, by helping them understand about feelings

original_text:
3. Pointing and naming
Pointing to and naming an object or person in the book will help your child learn new words. Children learn through repetition, so repeat the word and look for other opportunities to use the word (in the book or elsewhere).
text_to_read:
3. Pointing and naming
Pointing to and naming an object or person in the book will help your child learn new words. Children learn through repetition, so repeat the word and look for other opportunities to use the word (in the book or elsewhere).
label: Activity-Baby12-Calm-Book-sharing_a0242d4d-d2db-4d03-8a9b-079b831d6e3b_fe9efe8f-1dc0-4a6a-a1cb-7a7198e48d9d

original_text:
4. Be positive and supportive
Always respond positively to whatever your child says about the pictures. For example, if your child points to a red apple and says “Tomato”, you can say “Yes, you’re right, it’s red - it's an apple!”
text_to_read:
4. Be positive and supportive
Always respond positively to whatever your child says about the pictures. For example, if your child points to a red apple and says “Tomato”, you can say “Yes, you’re right, it’s red - it's an apple!”
label: Activity-Baby12-Calm-Book-sharing_fe983f6c-f188-4402-b3fe-5772aca344b7_c263a8df-7dd1-45cb-8c49-e22379d73cef

original_text: If your child knows a word and can say that word, ask “What’s that?” and give them the opportunity to say the word and point to it.
text_to_read: If your child knows a word and can say that word, ask “What’s that?” and give them the opportunity to say the word and point to it.
label: Activity-Baby12-Calm-Book-sharing_85754975-57e8-4e9e-aec2-fbe8d646c176_6cdd3a30-2c8e-4324-9b0d-81fa5e58581a

original_text:
5. Making actions and links
Connect things in the book with familiar things in your child’s world. For example, if the baby in the book is wearing shoes, ask your child to point out their own shoes. If someone in the book is waving, you and your child can do the same.
text_to_read:
5. Making actions and links
Connect things in the book with familiar things in your child’s world. For example, if the baby in the book is wearing shoes, ask your child to point out their own shoes. If someone in the book is waving, you and your child can do the same.
label: Activity-Baby12-Calm-Book-sharing_e9270987-af42-4950-a8a8-241833ddca9e_605b6773-446d-490c-a011-45dfc4960269

original_text:
6. Talking about feelings
Books are a great way for children to learn more about feelings. You can use your face and voice to help them understand emotion words like happy, sad, angry, or scared. You can use what is happening in the book to talk about your child’s own feelings, and why other people might feel a certain way.
text_to_read:
6. Talking about feelings
Books are a great way for children to learn more about feelings. You can use your face and voice to help them understand emotion words like happy, sad, angry, or scared. You can use what is happening in the book to talk about your child’s own feelings, and why other people might feel a certain way.
label: Activity-Baby12-Calm-Book-sharing_a9b7f715-f529-4c55-ba25-b3f11644c893_d408f09c-2518-4d2f-85ba-c7c9c6307c7c

original_text:
7. Babies and Books!
Even very young babies enjoy book-sharing and looking at the pictures together with a parent or caregiver. In fact, regular book-sharing helps their development and learning. And it is okay for them to put the book in their mouth - they are exploring!
text_to_read:
7. Babies and Books!

label: Activity-Baby12-Calm-Book-sharing_4171f21f-87c0-4415-beb6-1023aa660c84_b78e9f74-6f7a-4529-9bac-a2cef7cdbfda

original_text:
Here are some examples! 
“Look, she is smiling. Why do you think she is smiling? What made you smile today?”
“The monkey is sad because he is all on his own. Can you remember when you were last sad?”
“That tiger looks angry. Why do you think he is angry? Do you remember when I got angry this morning?”

original_text: The sound of a baby crying can be very distressing, especially for a parent. It is completely natural to want to make it stop. original_text:
Remember that you’re in charge of what they eat, but not how much. Newborns have stomach the size of a grape! They need to eat often (sometimes in the middle of the night. 
It’s important to build trust around eating, especially as your baby starts on solid food. Let them know you are listening to their wishes in the eating department. They’ll be ravenous again soon!

original_text: Check to see why your baby is in a bad mood. Are they tired or hungry? Or maybe they are not feeling well? Or maybe they need some more loving attention. Be a reassuring presence for your baby when they are having a difficult day.

original_text: Your baby will cry as soon as a caregiver’s attention is diverted and are cranky as well as clingy. Prioritise being there for them and give them physical contact when needed.

original_text: Pay close attention to your baby in case they try something dangerous! Just because they are able to play on their own now, doesn’t mean you can look away for long. Redirect mischievous behaviours into practice waving, imitation games, singing and moving games and pretending to talk on the phone!

original_text: Try to stay calm and support your toddler as they move through the tantrum. Your priority is to ensure that they don’t hurt themselves. Don’t add to your child’s anger by shouting and showing angry emotions. This won’t help.

1. Learn about private parts
2. Your body belongs to you
3. Bad secrets should be told

Type "1" to 3" to learn more about these tips. Type "N" to stop this tip.

original_text:
1. Learn about private parts

The parts of their body that go under people's underwear or a swimsuit are private parts. It is not OK for other people to touch or to ask to look at them, or ask them to look at or touch theirs.
text_to_read:
1. Learn about private parts

original_text:
2. Your body belongs to you

If someone tries to touch your children's private parts they must say NO and tell a grown up that they trust.
text_to_read:
2. Your body belongs to you

label: Content-Positive-Safe/unsafe-touch_2b647b05-28fc-4ea0-9870-7e0e69961470_d4fec002-4194-4099-adb2-9243db8b1e08

original_text:
3. Bad secrets should be told. 

Your children should tell you if there is a secret that makes them feel worried. You will not be angry. Only nice secrets - like a surprise birthday party - should be kept secret.

original_text: We are models of our children's behaviour. If we practice keeping safe distances, handwashing and treat others with compassion, our children and teenagers will do the same.
text_to_read: We are models of our children's behaviour. If we practice keeping safe distances, handwashing and treat others with compassion, our children and teenagers will do the same.
label: Content-Positive-Routines-part-3-and-song_e3a0caf6-a828-4cb4-a9f9-916b67c9b793_f29e06db-4ce2-43f6-b5f4-ac76ae9871be

original_text:
Children see and children do,
They like to be like me and you,
What you do and what you say,
Will help to shape them everyday!
text_to_read:
Children see and children do,

original_text: Routines will make your children feel safe and secure. Try to have regular mealtimes and bedtimes. Remember to schedule One-on-One time with your children, too!
text_to_read: Routines will make your children feel safe and secure. Try to have regular mealtimes and bedtimes. Remember to schedule One-on-One time with your children, too!
label: Content-Positive-Routines-part-2_abe0f429-1e91-46f0-a812-c1dad34b8ce2_22dbdb6a-df29-4969-ad90-da7fe23d72c1

original_text: Did you know that teens actually like having responsibilities? It makes them feel more independent and grown up. Allow your teen to choose a special job that helps out.
text_to_read: Did you know that teens actually like having responsibilities? It makes them feel more independent and grown up. Allow your teen to choose a special job that helps out.
label: Content-Positive-Routines-part-2_886ac764-40bc-47db-b97d-2a9b4a2b3a5a_217887c9-4637-4e57-8b17-10547d1915e9

original_text: As your teen shows more responsibility, you can also give them extra privileges. Try to share responsibilities equally amongst women/men and girls/boys. Praise your teen whenever they do their job!
text_to_read: As your teen shows more responsibility, you can also give them extra privileges. Try to share responsibilities equally amongst women/men and girls/boys. Praise your teen whenever they do their job!
label: Content-Positive-Routines-part-2_edea4b81-8613-4135-8c60-a8e3b36ded28_ba3dcc31-9db3-4a13-86f7-b0474caa237d

original_text: When you teach your children about safe distancing, you keep your whole family safe. You keep others safe, too!
text_to_read: When you teach your children about safe distancing, you keep your whole family safe. You keep others safe, too!

original_text: You can even make safe distancing into a game where children earn points for keeping at least 1 metre away from others in public. The one with the most points can win a simple, free reward like extra One-on-One Time

original_text:
Crazy Chicken
•	Shake your left hands in the air 8 times while counting to 8 
•	Do it as fast and loud as you can
•	Repeat with your other hand. Repeat with both feet
•	Do it 7 times, then 6 times and continue until you get to 1.
•	Everyone calls out “Crazy chicken” and does their best crazy chicken dance!

•	Everyone calls out “Crazy chicken” and does their best crazy chicken dance!
label: Activity-Child09-Active-Crazy-chicken_3ca52b66-89aa-49b0-9c2b-443b21ab7d2d_8abff6c5-a7f3-4fc4-a8ed-521e42c64d54

original_text:
Drawing
•	Children love to draw! It helps build creativity
•	Get some pens or crayons and a piece of paper or cardboard
•	Let your children freely whatever they want
•	While your child is drawing, use words to describe what they are doing: “I see you are drawing a person” or “I see you are making lines with the red crayon.”
•	You can also have fun drawing next to them
•	Put their drawings up on the wall, refrigerator, or outside to decorate the house – it will make your children feel appreciated!

original_text:
Self-portrait
•	Here’s how your children can draw a picture of themselves!
•	Find a big piece of paper or cardboard. It needs to be the same length or slightly longer than the height of your child
•	Ask your child to lie down on the paper. Carefully draw the outline of your child.
•	Now let your child fill in the outline: face, hair, clothes, shoes, or anything they want!
•	Ask your child to draw things that they like and do not like outside of the outline
•	Have a conversation with your child about these things. You may learn something about your child!
•	You can put their outline up in their room or anywhere in the house – it will make your children feel appreciated!

original_text:
Transform the object
•	Every day household items like brooms, mops, or scarfs can become fun props for games
•	Place an object in the center of the room and whenever someone has an idea, they jump in and show the rest what the object can be
•	For example, a broom might be ridden as a horse or a microphone or a guitar!

original_text: The sound of a baby crying can be very distressing, especially for a parent. It is completely natural to want to make it stop. You might also think that you are not a good parent or that your baby is crying to spite you. But all babies cry. It is one of the main ways a baby can tell you that something is wrong.

original_text:
Here are some tips that might help when your baby cries:

1. Why babies cry
2. Respond as soon as you can
3. Check to see why your baby is crying
4. Comfort your baby
5. Take a break if you need it
6. Be gentle and patient with yourself
7. If you think your baby is injured or sick, call or visit a clinic

To learn more about one of these, type "1" to "7". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.

original_text:
1. Why do babies cry?

Crying is a normal part of your baby's development. Sometimes babies even have crying patterns. Crying usually increases at 2-3 weeks old and is generally highest when your baby is around 6 to 8 weeks. Often babies will start crying less around 3 to 4 months. Of course, remember that every baby is different!
text_to_read:
1. Why do babies cry?

Crying is a normal part of your baby's development. Sometimes babies even have crying patterns. Crying usually increases at 2-3 weeks old and is generally highest when your baby is around 6 to 8 weeks. Often babies will start crying less around 3 to 4 months. Of course, remember that every baby is different!
label: Content-Extra-Behave-Crying_ad138512-a2b4-4b06-b871-de2cefda9141_11eccf61-7e9a-415a-8f0c-90b8cd2c63a8

original_text:
2. Respond as soon as you can

Go to your baby when you hear them crying. You will not spoil your baby by picking them up. Babies who are carried and cuddled frequently, during both fussy and contented periods, may actually cry less.
text_to_read:
2. Respond as soon as you can

Go to your baby when you hear them crying. You will not spoil your baby by picking them up. Babies who are carried and cuddled frequently, during both fussy and contented periods, may actually cry less.
label: Content-Extra-Behave-Crying_9251cb81-0680-4be0-8952-40c03b132cc2_568ef0bf-ca08-42f6-95eb-a11370fbb4a9

original_text:
3.  Check to see why your baby is crying

There are lots of reasons why babies cry. It might be hunger, pain, too much going on, rough handling, feeling cold/hot, wanting contact or attention, or feeling irritable. Babies can cry when they sense tension in the room. And sometimes they cry for no reason at all!
text_to_read:
3.  Check to see why your baby is crying

There are lots of reasons why babies cry. It might be hunger, pain, too much going on, rough handling, feeling cold/hot, wanting contact or attention, or feeling irritable. Babies can cry when they sense tension in the room. And sometimes they cry for no reason at all!
label: Content-Extra-Behave-Crying_4dcb6e29-70d9-4ec4-91de-32b065ee6076_2b12b716-c205-4b51-9181-380c35ee92cd

original_text:
4. Comfort your baby

Try swaddling, gently rocking, or singing or soft music. You might need to feed your baby or change their diaper. They may be too hot or too cold. Or maybe they just need to be held. Take a Pause and try to relax - your baby can actually sense tension from you, too!
text_to_read:
4. Comfort your baby

Try swaddling, gently rocking, or singing or soft music. You might need to feed your baby or change their diaper. They may be too hot or too cold. Or maybe they just need to be held. Take a Pause and try to relax - your baby can actually sense tension from you, too!
label: Content-Extra-Behave-Crying_fed5dc11-84fe-4e41-9bf5-0d4a9152b789_222d373f-c179-4f37-9f5e-1de759d82945

original_text:
5. Take a break!

If you are getting angry because your baby won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe place and walk away for a bit. Check on your baby every 5-10 minutes.
text_to_read:
5. Take a break!

If you are getting angry because your baby won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe place and walk away for a bit. Check on your baby every 5-10 minutes.
label: Content-Extra-Behave-Crying_06c818ce-cc12-48d7-a429-514987857554_7a836ad2-b1cf-4620-b2ad-917710c20fe5

original_text:
6. Be gentle and patient with yourself

We know that this is not easy. You are not a bad parent if your baby continues to cry after you have done all they can to calm them. You are doing your best!

original_text:
7. If you think your baby is injured or sick, call or visit a clinic

If your baby cries for a long time and does not stop, they might be injured or sick. You should seek medical help immediately.

original_text:
Ship to Shore 
•	A fun active game where children learn different parts of a boat. Everyone must go to the place or activity that you call out
•	“Bow” means run to the front of the boat (room)
•	“Stern” means run to the back of the boat
•	“Starboard” means run to the right side and “Port” means run to the right side
•	“Climb the rigging”: pretend to climb
•	“Clean the deck”: pretend to clean the floor
•	“Lifeboat, [number] people!”: hold hands in a circle with that many people and do knee bends
•	Everyone not in a lifeboat must swim!

•	“Lifeboat, [number] people!”: hold hands in a circle with that many people and do knee bends

original_text:
Here is something fun to help you let go of stress:

Choose a song that reflects what you need in this moment. Do you need a gentle song to soothe your tired soul or an upbeat song to help you shake some stress out?

Make a space and move your body to the music. Remember to breathe while you move. Let your breath and the movement go together.

Even a few minutes of movement can be enough to release stress and lift your mood!

original_text:
Let’s use the magic power of three stay present and relax. 

Name three sounds you can hear right now.
Name three smells you can smell right now. 
Name your three favourite foods. 

What are three things you can be grateful for right now?
They don’t have to be big.
 
At the end of a tough day, thinking of three things to be grateful for can help us find the courage to try again tomorrow.

original_text:
Do you sometimes feel like you are getting everything wrong?

Take a moment to think over the day. Think of one thing you did today that you are proud of.
Wrap your arms around your body and give yourself a hug.
Think of one thing you did today that you don’t feel proud of. What can you do differently tomorrow?
And wrap your arms around your body and give yourself a hug.

It’s ok. You are doing your best so be kind to yourself. Get some rest and try again tomorrow!

original_text:
Do you sometimes feel your feelings are too much?
Talk to someone. 
Talk to someone you trust. Talk to a friend. Talk to family. Talk to a tree.
Get your worries off your chest and then let them go. Even if it’s just for a moment. 
How do you feel now?
A joy shared is twice the joy. A problem shared is half the problem.

original_text:
Here's an activity to relax your body:

Sit comfortably and close your eyes if you can.
Imagine a golden ring scanning your body from your feet to your head. 
Pay attention as it moves up and down your body. Are there any areas that feel tense? Numb? Painful? 
Focus on those areas for a moment. Breathe in to the area and when you breathe out, try to let go of any tension or pain. 
Do this for a few breaths. 
Open your eyes. How does your body feel now?

Try this next time you find yourself lying in bed unable to sleep!

original_text:
Notice your connection with the ground beneath you.
What parts of your body touch the ground? What parts of your body don’t? 
Notice where it feels warm and where it feels cool.
Feel the ground underneath you supporting you. Let your body sink into the support of the ground. 

Try this next time you feel alone or are doing a mundane activity like washing up. It can really help!

original_text:
Here is a short relaxation activity for you:

Sit down and close your eyes
How many sounds can you hear? 
Listen to the sounds inside and outside the room. Count them on your fingers.
After ten seconds, how many fingers do you have up? What sounds did you hear?
Try again for another ten seconds. 
Did you hear any new sounds? Did you hear any sounds inside your own body?
Notice how you feel now.

original_text:
Use the magic power of three to stay connected and relax.

Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
Breath out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
Breath out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
Breath out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.

How do you feel now? Do you feel any different? Deep breathing helps our whole body and mind to calm down.

original_text:
Do you ever feel something so strongly that you want to run away from it?

Instead of moving away from the feeling, let’s move towards it for a moment.
It’s ok. Close your eyes if you feel comfortable. Take a deep breath.

Become curious. Where are you feeling it in your body? Is it hot or cold? Hard or soft? Tight or loose?
Ask yourself some questions. What is it telling me? What does it need? How can I be kind to myself in this moment?

If your mind starts to wander, it’s normal. Just bring it back to the feeling. Keep breathing and feeling.
Reassure yourself. It’s ok to feel. Feeling is healing!

original_text:
2 Truths, 1 Lie
•	Think of three statements about yourself. Two must be true and one must be a lie.
•	It might help to think of wishes, dreams, experiences at school, likes or dislikes. For example, I hate bananas, my favourite subject is science, and I really wish I could sing. 
•	Say them to your teenager. Ask them to guess which one is a lie. 
•	Did they guess correctly? Was it a surprise?
•	Now ask them to do the same. Did you learn something new about each other?
text_to_read:

•	Say them to your teenager. Ask them to guess which one is a lie. 
•	Did they guess correctly? Was it a surprise?
•	Now ask them to do the same. Did you learn something new about each other?

•	Ask each other questions. They can be any questions about things you like or what you did today.
•	The only rule is that you can’t answer Yes, No or Maybe
•	How long can you last? How creative can you get with your answers?
•	Swap over and play again!

The Interrupter
•	Choose a storyteller to start making up a story
•	Story listeners can interrupt with a word at any time
•	Storyteller needs to fit that word in their story
•	Try with a different storyteller!
text_to_read:
The Interrupter
•	Choose a storyteller to start making up a story
•	Story listeners can interrupt with a word at any time
•	Storyteller needs to fit that word in their story
•	Try with a different storyteller!
label: Activity-Teen04-Calm-The-Interrupter_0cad6b2b-175d-4288-a0bd-d0debcbc7a7c_ee1d174e-cb47-433e-b530-d6f125df6ef1

original_text:
Superpowers
•	Think of a superpower. For example, going anywhere instantly, travelling in time, reading minds. 
•	Ask your teen “If you had the superpower to […] how would you use it?
•	Encourage them to give their superhero a name and act it out. 
•	Now let them choose a super power for you
•	Make sure you act it out too!

original_text:
How was your day?
•	Ask each other, “What made you happy today?”
•	Ask each other, “What was difficult today?”
•	Ask each other, “How can we help you?”
•	Try to do this together every day, when you are eating together or before bed

original_text:
All children behave badly sometimes. Here are a list of typical behaviours that can challenging for parents:

1. Crying a lot
2. Problems sleeping
3. Acting clingy
4. Whining for things
5. Bad tempered or moody
6. Problems eating
7. Stubborn or fussy
8. Behaving naughty
9. Temper tantrums

Please type the number that describes the most challenging behaviour for you to manage with @fields.survey_behave_name. You can also type "0" if you do not want to answer.

original_text:
Here are 6 simple tips that you can do to support children living with disabilities: 

1. Keep your child safe and well
2. Try to understand what they are feeling
3. Communicate and talk with them
4. Praise them!
5. Make things that you do the same every day to help them feel secure
6. Ask for help if you can

Type "1" to "6" to learn more about each tip. Type "N" to stop this tip.
text_to_read:
Here are 6 simple tips that you can do to support children living with disabilities:

2. Try to understand what they are feeling
3. Communicate and talk with them
4. Praise them!
5. Make things that you do the same every day to help them feel secure
6. Ask for help if you can

Type "1" to "6" to learn more about each tip. Type "N" to stop this tip.

original_text:
Step 1. Keep your child safe and well 

• Keep your country's COVID-19 rules, and also help your child to be active - do whatever exercise you can with them inside or outside your home
• Keep emergency contact numbers somewhere easy to see
text_to_read:
Step 1. Keep your child safe and well 

• Keep your country's COVID-19 rules, and also help your child to be active - do whatever exercise you can with them inside or outside your home
• Keep emergency contact numbers somewhere easy to see
label: Content-Extra-Disability_83902904-a1cf-4d46-a0d0-ec08228619ba_01811c28-f86a-429a-ad2b-37f45ef04bd9

original_text:
Step 2. Try to understand how they are feeling

• Your child may be feeling a lot of stress, anxiety, and frustration.
• Tell them that you love them
• Praise them for being good and for trying to be good!
text_to_read:
Step 2. Try to understand how they are feeling

original_text:
Step 3. Talking and communicating with your child

• Get down to your child’s level when you speak. 
• Look at them and smile
• Give them time to tell you or show you what they think
• Tell your child that you understand

original_text:
Step 4. Praise them!

• Praise them for behaving well, and for trying. 
• Focus on what they can do, not what they can't.
• Only help children when they need it. It is also good to build independence!
text_to_read:

original_text:
Step 5. Make daily plans to help them feel secure

• Having things that are the same each day helps children feel secure and safe.
• Make a daily plan that includes some things they like to do.
• Help your child connect to friends and family members through phone, writing cards, or drawing pictures.
text_to_read:

original_text:

• Share the load with other adult family members.
•  You are not alone! Keep connected with people who understand your situation.

original_text:
Infant (0–1 year) needs:
• Us to provide food, sleep, cleaning, comfort and safety.
• A strong bond with parent/ caregiver.
• Lots of play and attention - the most active time of brain development is during the first 1000 days of life!
text_to_read:
Infant (0–1 year) needs:

• Lots of play and attention - the most active time of brain development is during the first 1000 days of life!
label: Content-Extra-Development_d6b2555b-dc70-4d0e-afcc-a984c83e37ce_d63f8065-7fe2-490a-95bb-2e64a4983eb1

original_text:
Toddlers (2-3 years):
• Become a curious little explorer - watch out for climbing! 
• Learn through play and trying things out
• Want to learn how to do new things (like getting dressed) and make their own decisions.
• Want your praise and your approval
text_to_read:

original_text:

• More interested in learning in school.
• Start to want independence and trust.

original_text:
Infants (0-1):
• 0–6 months: Smile, babble and cry to attract your attention. We should provide care, cuddling and protection.
• 6–11 months: Cling to you, especially when feeling insecure or frightened. 
• 12–23 months: Start to walk, talk and explore things around them!
text_to_read:

• 6–11 months: Cling to you, especially when feeling insecure or frightened. 
• 12–23 months: Start to walk, talk and explore things around them!
label: Content-Extra-Development_4d2ce354-4f61-46bb-a288-0d910071eea2_006ade8c-6f5e-41b2-a283-227056d29049

original_text:
Toddlers (2-3 years):
• Start speaking in sentences and  learning new words.
• Does not like to lose or take turns, but sharing can be taught.
• May express feelings in dramatic ways (like screaming on the floor!). Can start to learn how to manage their feelings.
text_to_read:
Toddlers (2-3 years):
• Start speaking in sentences and  learning new words.
• Does not like to lose or take turns, but sharing can be taught.
• May express feelings in dramatic ways (like screaming on the floor!). Can start to learn how to manage their feelings.
label: Content-Extra-Development_7a39e351-960c-4fa0-8c4f-69864ec0b62d_2defc4cd-b2bb-4a48-9c63-ca4889315f81

original_text:
Young teenagers (10-12 years)
• May answer back to adults to show that they “know”.
• Can be very self-conscious and sensitive
• Can learn to better manage anger and tolerate frustration.
text_to_read:
Young teenagers (10-12 years)
• May answer back to adults to show that they “know”.
• Can be very self-conscious and sensitive
• Can learn to better manage anger and tolerate frustration.
label: Content-Extra-Development_2d460c9b-7536-47b5-95ca-5feb94e1c2f3_dc725ff7-b6bf-4966-b792-10890fc70fb5

original_text:
Middle teenagers (13-14 years)
• Begin to challenge adult rules
• Are often insecure and confused.
• Feelings get hurt easily and have mood swings
• Try to be the boss and are unhappy if they lose.
text_to_read:
Middle teenagers (13-14 years)
• Begin to challenge adult rules
• Are often insecure and confused.
• Feelings get hurt easily and have mood swings
• Try to be the boss and are unhappy if they lose.
label: Content-Extra-Development_241d19c9-8910-4b5d-88af-a1d59fb8b6cc_adba2f14-0afe-4b84-911f-9ac559e414c4

original_text:
Young children (4-6 years):
• Same as toddlers, but also...
• Learn through actions and play.
• Develop friendships with other children
• Find it difficult to separate make-believe from reality. Still express feelings in dramatic ways!
text_to_read:
Young children (4-6 years):
• Same as toddlers, but also...
• Learn through actions and play.
• Develop friendships with other children
• Find it difficult to separate make-believe from reality. Still express feelings in dramatic ways!
label: Content-Extra-Development_17d312ac-6a0d-4ce7-99ba-8aa7c3b9a778_9150d233-baca-4131-a33e-25f0cdd3cb76

original_text:
Middle teenagers (13-14 years)
• Their friends are important and affect their choices
• Need some freedom but also reliable rules that don't change
• Need affection, reassurance, self-esteem, encouragement to believe in their abilities
text_to_read:
Middle teenagers (13-14 years)
• Their friends are important and affect their choices
• Need some freedom but also reliable rules that don't change
• Need affection, reassurance, self-esteem, encouragement to believe in their abilities
label: Content-Extra-Development_c176651d-8e4b-4aa5-ad7b-a8b4059afe11_7769ac78-d1f4-4c37-8923-3e8e35c4d070

original_text:
Young children (4-6 years):
• May talk a lot; ask many questions. We should be honest when we reply! Our child may ask again if they don't understand or want to know more
• Does not like to lose, share or take turns, but losing and taking turns can be taught.
text_to_read:
Young children (4-6 years):
• May talk a lot; ask many questions. We should be honest when we reply! Our child may ask again if they don't understand or want to know more
• Does not like to lose, share or take turns, but losing and taking turns can be taught.
label: Content-Extra-Development_38de05e1-8466-46c8-8078-de2c2480f8c4_b6c47487-6740-4231-b5f4-d8c8c4865aef

original_text:
Older teenagers (15–19 years)
• The teen years are the second most active time of brain development!
• Your child is almost an adult, they are able to communicate with you about
almost anything.
• They can think about new ideas, develop their own ideals and set their
own course.
text_to_read:
Older teenagers (15–19 years)
• The teen years are the second most active time of brain development!
• Your child is almost an adult, they are able to communicate with you about
almost anything.
• They can think about new ideas, develop their own ideals and set their
own course.
label: Content-Extra-Development_00ede26a-cacd-428c-84a4-69ac7f529d06_6d538605-59fe-4b10-b725-ee955f8888fe

original_text:
Older children (7-9 years)
• Same early childhood, but also…
• Interested in learning at school.
• Starts to want independence and trust.
• Wants to spend time with other children.
text_to_read:
Older children (7-9 years)
• Same early childhood, but also…
• Interested in learning at school.
• Starts to want independence and trust.
• Wants to spend time with other children.
label: Content-Extra-Development_64a763a1-ad30-4240-b22c-d52580001bfe_06b3c6f2-c23c-4dfb-9353-8946e822a08f

original_text:
Older teenagers (15–19 years)
• They are forming their own identity and have a growing sense of their
sexuality
• They may prefer being with peers more than with you
• They may show risk-taking behaviours, frequent mood swings, and rebellious
attitudes. They can also have exciting new ideas!
text_to_read:

• They are forming their own identity and have a growing sense of their

• They may prefer being with peers more than with you

label: Content-Extra-Development_29f962da-fa94-4205-8973-3eb00dbf3fe2_38d5a3aa-e1e9-4f91-8984-72a82f3b64dd

original_text:
Older children (7-9 years)
• May start to ask questions about religion
• May answer back to adults to show that they “know”.
• Can be very self-conscious and sensitive. May be very active. By now they should be getting better at managing anger and frustration.
text_to_read:
Older children (7-9 years)

• May answer back to adults to show that they “know”.
• Can be very self-conscious and sensitive. May be very active. By now they should be getting better at managing anger and frustration.
label: Content-Extra-Development_72532618-97d6-4ff7-a4dd-b2d815322dd2_ac3b483c-6cba-4b3d-a0a9-9e027a0a0956

original_text:
The most important things that you can do for your teen in this stage are:
• Continue providing love, support and guidance and build a strong
parent-child connection
• Monitor who their friends are, have clear rules to keep them safe
• Nurture their independence
text_to_read:
The most important things that you can do for your teen in this stage are:
• Continue providing love, support and guidance and build a strong
parent-child connection
• Monitor who their friends are, have clear rules to keep them safe
• Nurture their independence
label: Content-Extra-Development_954bdc34-c28c-432d-a3e0-d88ec9ce7f90_64b08361-7672-498d-b307-9c17264727ae

original_text:
• Be patient and accepting of the person they are becoming - even if it is not what you had imagined
• Encourage them to begin to take responsibility for the future
• Keep supporting them and loving them so that they feel comfortable, secure, and safe

original_text:
Dream Travel
•	You can’t travel but you can dream! Ask your teen these questions
•	Where do you want to travel? How long will you be away? What will you pack? What will you do? What will you see ?
•	Look at a map together if you have one.
•	Choose a country that they’ve never heard of and look it up together online.

original_text:
Mirror
•	This game can be played in pairs or even as a group
•	Stand facing each other or in a circle  
•	One person leads first while everyone else must copy, trying to move exactly at the same time as the leader.
•	Make sure the leader moves slowly enough for everyone to follow! Explore moving different body parts and in different levels.
•	After a while, switch who is leading. Give everyone a chance to lead
•	Try it with no leaders!

original_text:
Memory game – “When COVID-19 ends…”
•	First person says, “When COVID-19 ends, I am going to… (e.g., go to the park)”
•	Second person adds to first person, “When COVID-19 ends, I am going to the park and… (e.g., visit my best friend”
•	Each person adds to the previous trying to think of all of the fun things to do when COVID-19 ends

Make Housework Fun
•	Household chores aren’t fun… or are they? You can make them into a game, like this. 
•	There’s a fire on the mountain! Run, run, run!
•	There’s a fire on the mountain! Run, run, run!
•	Touch something red. 
•	There’s a fire on the mountain! Run, run, run!
•	There’s a fire on the mountain! Run, run, run!
•	Jump up and down ten times.
•	There’s a fire on the mountain! Run, run, run!
•	There’s a fire on the mountain! Run, run, run!
•	Put the shoes in the shoe rack.

original_text:
A Short Pause
•	Sit down and close your eyes
•	Listen to your breath as it goes in and out. 
•	Notice how you feel. 
•	Take a few more deep breaths.
•	When you are ready open your eyes again. Do you feel any different? 
•	Remind yourself that “Everything is ok”

original_text:
Making a budget with your children and teens.
A budget is how we decide what we will spend our money on, even in stressful times. Making a budget together helps children understand that we all need to make hard decisions in difficult times. It can also help you have enough at the end of the month so that you need to borrow less.
text_to_read:

original_text:
Step 1: What do we spend on now?

• Get a piece of paper (or old newspaper or a cardboard box) and a pen.
• Draw pictures of all the things that you and your family spend money on each month.
• Write next to each picture how much each thing costs.
• Add up how much money you have to spend each month.

original_text:
Step 3: Build your own budget

• Find a bag of stones or anything with lots of bits. This is your money for the month.
• As a family, decide what you will spend on what, and put the stones on your picture.
• If you can save even a tiny amount for the future, or for an emergency  – it can make a big difference over time.

6. Report and seek help

original_text:
1. Learn about risks and dangers

• Adults targeting children for sexual purposes on social media, gaming, and messaging platforms.
• Harmful content – like violence, hating women, hating foreigners, encouraging suicide and self-harm, misinformation, pornography
• Teens sharing personal information and sexual photos or videos of themselves.
• Cyberbullying from other young people and strangers.
text_to_read:

• Cyberbullying from other young people and strangers.

original_text:
2. Tech fixes to protect your children online:

• Turn on SafeSearch on your browser to filter adult content.
https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/entertainment-search-engines/
• Set up parental controls.
https://www.internetmatters.org/parental-controls/
• Set up strict privacy settings on online apps and games.
 https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/social-media/
• Cover webcams when not in use.

original_text:
Help your child learn how to keep personal information private, especially from strangers – some people are not who they say they are!
Remind your children that what goes online stays online (messages, photos, and videos).
 Actively supervise children’s time online, including computers, smartphones, and tablets.

original_text:
4. Spend time with your child or teen online

Get to know how your child experiences the digital world.
Explore websites, social media, games, and apps together.
Talk to your teen on how to report things that aren't OK.

Common Sense Media has great advice for apps, games and entertainment for different ages.
https://www.commonsensemedia.org/app-reviews

original_text:
5. Build open communication and trusting relationships
Tell your children that if they experience something online (or anywhere) that makes them feel upset, uncomfortable, or scared, they can talk to you and you will not get mad or punish them.

original_text:
6. Report and seek help

INHOPE Hotlines and IWF portals and the Child Helpline in your country to get support if you or your children experience online violence or other things that are not acceptable.

INHOPE Hotlines: https://www.inhope.org/EN#hotlineReferral
IWF portals: https://report.iwf.org.uk/en
Child Helpline: https://www.childhelplineinternational.org/

original_text:
Here are 6 simple steps that you can do to support family harmony at home:

1. Be a model of behaviour for your kids
2. Keep it positive
3. Listen carefully to others
4. Share the loads
5. Take care of yourself
6. Do nice things together as a family.

Type "1" to 6" to learn more about these tips. Type "N" to stop this tip.

original_text:
Step 4. Share the load

Looking after children and other family members is difficult, but it’s much easier when responsibilities are shared. Try to share household chores, childcare, and other tasks equally amongst family members
text_to_read:
Step 4. Share the load

Looking after children and other family members is difficult, but it’s much easier when responsibilities are shared. Try to share household chores, childcare, and other tasks equally amongst family members
label: Content-Extra-Family_1d09484e-a0f4-4c28-bbdd-4ab06ad2eec6_b1663bfe-8688-4db9-a2e6-c2309108ce8b

original_text:
Step 5. Take care of yourself

Create a schedule for time “on” and time “off” with other adults in your household. It is okay to ask for help when you are feeling tired or stressed so that you can take a break
text_to_read:
Step 5. Take care of yourself

label: Content-Extra-Family_2c415bec-1a27-44c5-bd3c-7e6d947f0942_319409c6-d0c2-4e58-8005-80ecc5e30e17

original_text:
Step 6. Do nice things together as a family

Let each family member take turns choosing a whole family activity. Find ways to spend time alone with other adults in your home, too!

original_text:
Step 1. Be a model of behaviour for your kids

How we talk and behave in front of our children is a big influence on how they behave too! Try to talk kindly to everyone in the family, adults and children.
text_to_read:
Step 1. Be a model of behaviour for your kids

How we talk and behave in front of our children is a big influence on how they behave too! Try to talk kindly to everyone in the family, adults and children.
label: Content-Extra-Family_7c5cea2a-589e-4052-acc1-2f177e9ab04f_097c4730-2585-4e50-b8ae-531007e97faf

original_text:
Step 2. Use positive language. It works!

Tell others what you want them to do instead of what you don’t want them to do: Instead of “Stop shouting,” try “Please speak more quietly”
text_to_read:
Step 2. Use positive language. It works!

Tell others what you want them to do instead of what you don’t want them to do: Instead of “Stop shouting,” try “Please speak more quietly”
label: Content-Extra-Family_b60a44fc-1e3b-4e8b-8766-4d278c92103b_b467da12-5573-48b4-8dc6-8e39e88ee381

original_text:
Step 3. Be a great listener

Listen to others when they are talking with you. Be open and show them that you hear what they are saying. It can help to summarise what you have heard before responding: “What I hear you saying is…”

original_text:
Step 2. It is OK not to know the answers.

It is fine to say “We don’t know, but we are working on it; or we don’t know, ‘but we think’.”  Use this as an opportunity to learn something new with your child. The WHO and UNICEF websites are great first steps to learn.

WHO: https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/advice-for-public
UNICEF: https://www.unicef.org/coronavirus/covid-19

original_text:
Step 1. Create a routine around learning and schoolwork

Make a daily plan with your child for when they can spend time doing educational activities. This can include structured schoolwork and other activities online, reading, writing, or arts. Allow flexibility and time for play and relaxation too.
text_to_read:
Step 1. Create a routine around learning and schoolwork

original_text:
Step 2. Make learning fun and playful

Children learn best when learning is fun! Try to find ways to make learning playful to keep your child interested and engaged. Type "Help" if you ever need any fun ideas!
text_to_read:

label: Content-Extra-Education_7cba124c-eebe-4315-a752-feb59831e4d2_fcacd283-b500-422b-b9a4-b394ce158b4e

original_text:
Step 5. Support your child when they go back to school

Tell your child that it is okay to feel scared or worried about going back to school. Allow your child to share how they are feeling. It is also normal if your child behaves different to their usual behaviour. Discuss how going to school might be different and how they can protect themselves from COVID-19. Ask them how their day went and support them if they experienced any difficulties.
text_to_read:

original_text:
Step 3. Remember that you are a parent NOT a substitute teacher! 

Your role is to support your child by creating a space to learn. You do not need to know all the answers. Help them explore their interests and ask questions. Go at your child's pace and be patient with yourself.
text_to_read:

original_text:
Step 4. Stay connected with your child's school and teachers

Find out how to stay in touch with your children’s teacher or school to stay informed, ask questions and get more guidance. If you are struggling or know someone who is struggling with school work or the home situation, please discuss this with a teacher that you feel close to. Parent groups or community groups can also be a good way to support each other with your home schooling.

original_text:
Peek-a-Boo! 
• Cover your face with your hands. 
• Quickly show your face and say "Peek-a-Boo!" or "Hello!" Babies love it!
text_to_read:
Peek-a-Boo! 
• Cover your face with your hands. 
• Quickly show your face and say "Peek-a-Boo!" or "Hello!" Babies love it!
label: Activity-Baby02-Active-Peek-a-boo!_790ca352-fe05-4349-a5b0-b3a40bf6dcc2_b4076fb1-d642-4fe6-970c-ea7400a54fb2

original_text:
Funny Faces
•	Look at your baby in the eyes and make different funny faces. 
•	Make a big face. Make a small face. Make a happy face. Make a surprised face. 
•	Which ones make your baby smile or laugh? Do them again, even bigger this time!
•	Play with different feelings and add sounds. 
•	Copy their facial expressions too. Exaggerate them to make them funny.
•	Always end on a positive expression!

•	Copy their facial expressions too. Exaggerate them to make them funny.

original_text:
Mirror Game
• Get to your baby's level so they can see you and hear you. 
• Copy their facial expressions and sounds. 
• It is so simple while creating a strong bond between you and your baby!
text_to_read:
Mirror Game

label: Activity-Baby01-Active-Mirror-game_689145fc-2c09-4435-9ea5-3bda3291417a_3a26419d-d000-4eea-a425-00da140211d3

original_text:
The Sun is Coming! 
•	Lie your baby on their back after washing them or changing their diaper
•	Tell them the sun is coming! Wiggle your fingers like sunrays above their head and make your face a big smiling sun.
•	Tell them the wind is coming! Blow softly over their body.
•	Tell them the rain is coming! Use your fingers to gently pat over their whole body like light raindrops.
•	Tell them the clouds are coming! Wrap the towel or cloth around them like a blanket and cuddle them 
•	Play with different weathers. Which one does your baby like best?
•	Add sound effects or make it into a little song. Use the tune of another song you know!

original_text:
Shakers
•	Find an empty, clean plastic bottle or pot with a lid that closes tight.
•	Fill it with sand, stones, uncooked rice, beans or any small objects that make an interesting sound. 
•	Move your body as you shake it in front of your baby
•	If it is safe, give it to your baby to shake!
•	Get creative! Can you find something colourful or try it with water? 
•	What sounds does your baby like?
text_to_read:
Shakers

•	If it is safe, give it to your baby to shake!
•	Get creative! Can you find something colourful or try it with water? 
•	What sounds does your baby like?
label: Activity-Baby05-Active-Shakers_51d6bd57-aa84-4f79-af7e-52f441bef785_8d10d7ba-7af7-42f4-b48d-37c7e1a4b3f8

original_text:
Musical Toes
•	Put your baby on their back
•	Wiggle their toe and say, “This little toe goes [funny sound]”
•	Make a funny sound for each toe
•	Play with different sounds. For example, animal sounds, popping sounds, squeaky sounds, fart sounds. 
•	Repeat this for all ten toes. 
•	Try to make the last toe the biggest and funniest sound!

•	Repeat this for all ten toes. 
•	Try to make the last toe the biggest and funniest sound!
label: Activity-Baby06-Active-Musical-Toes_c4b89d3f-ef33-46e4-8f88-f42d2685c30c_8eb0be23-ed69-48df-9f0d-7e29f52135d2

original_text:
Down in a ditch!
•	Sit on a chair and put your toddler on your lap facing you. Hold them firmly under the arms.
•	Gently bounce your legs and say in a soft voice “Baby horse, baby horse, baby horse, baby horse”
•	Bounce your legs a bit more and say a bit louder “Little horse, little horse, little horse, little horse”
•	Bounce your legs more and say louder “Big horse, big horse, big horse, big horse”
•	When you call out “Down in a ditch!” open your knees and let your child drop down between them. Make sure you hold them so they don’t fall far!
text_to_read:
Down in a ditch!

•	Gently bounce your legs and say in a soft voice “Baby horse, baby horse, baby horse, baby horse”
•	Bounce your legs a bit more and say a bit louder “Little horse, little horse, little horse, little horse”
•	Bounce your legs more and say louder “Big horse, big horse, big horse, big horse”
•	When you call out “Down in a ditch!” open your knees and let your child drop down between them. Make sure you hold them so they don’t fall far!
label: Activity-Baby07-Active-Down-in-a-ditch!_0f50d834-c327-4685-a64c-229f52e5dc27_1814859b-6227-4d63-a21a-b83ecafc1d2d

original_text:
Dance Party
•	Put on your favourite music or sing your favourite song and dance around the room with your toddler. If you have a baby hold them while you dance. 
•	Dance in different ways or with different parts of your body
•	For example, “Dance like a monkey”, “Dance like a chicken” or “Let’s dance with our knees and hips”
•	Think up different instructions. Be seriously playful! 
•	When the music stops, everyone does a funny freeze
•	Notice what rhythms or movement they like!
text_to_read:

label: Activity-Baby08-Active-Dance-party_b2d37847-1ffc-44ab-a2d2-df88462d771c_f2398015-746b-43d0-887f-9265c7a19b49

original_text:
Lullaby
•	When your baby or toddler cries, sing a soft song to calm you both down
•	Sing a soothing song you know or make up your own with a simple melody and some soothing words
•	Repeat it over and over in a rhythmical way. For example, “My little one, oh little one”
•	Sing the same song regularly so your child gets used to it!
text_to_read:

•	Sing the same song regularly so your child gets used to it!
label: Activity-Baby09-Calm-Lullaby_4f8b5e0a-631f-46ab-aebb-176385dae55d_8c38f795-7b9c-4f11-a353-8d55ec332cb1

original_text:
See It Be It
•	Look around you and name something that you can see. For example, a tree or a cup
•	Say to your child “I see a tree, let’s be it”
•	Countdown from 5 and make the shape of a tree with your bodies. Be as big and silly as possible.
•	Now let your child have a turn. What can they see?
•	If you can, go outside and be in nature. If you can’t, play it inside. 
•	When you’ve done it a few times, add moves and sounds!
text_to_read:

•	If you can, go outside and be in nature. If you can’t, play it inside. 
•	When you’ve done it a few times, add moves and sounds!
label: Activity-Baby10-Active-See-it-Be-it_1c5c23db-b202-44e3-8b15-704f510e9210_ee56e70a-1c0c-4d34-bd3e-4a8cd3191161

Cooking together
•	Children love to do what you do!
•	Let your baby play with pots and spoons while you are making dinner

original_text:
At the End of the Day
•	At the end of each day, take a minute to think about the day.  
•	Talk your child about one positive or fun thing they did.
•	Praise yourself for one thing you did well today.
•	Think of one thing that you are grateful for.  
•	You are a star!

original_text:
Rain on the Mountain
•	Call out, “There’s rain on the mountain”
•	Everyone else replies “Run, run, run” while running around the space. 
•	Call out different instructions. For example, touch something red or hop like a frog
•	Keep playing and change the instructions each time. 
•	You can use this as a fun way to learn colours or even tidy up!

original_text:
Listening to Sounds
•	Sit down and close your eyes
•	How many sounds can you hear? Listen to the sounds inside and outside the room. Count them on your fingers
•	After ten seconds, how many fingers do you have up? What sounds did you hear?
•	Try again for another ten seconds. 
•	Can you hear any new sounds? Can you hear any sounds inside your own body?
•	Notice how you feel and ask your child how they are feeling.
